verses.roman:
dorbhyām utkṛtta-mūlābhyāṁ
babhau rakta-sravo 'suraḥ
chinna-pakṣo yathā gotraḥ
khād bhraṣṭo vajriṇā hataḥ

synonyms: dorbhyām—from the two arms; utkṛtta-mūlābhyām—cut from the very root; babhau—was; rakta-sravaḥ—profusely discharging blood; asuraḥ—Vṛtrāsura; chinna-pakṣaḥ—whose wings are cut; yathā—just as; gotraḥ—a mountain; khāt—from the sky; bhraṣṭaḥ—falling; vajriṇā—by Indra, the carrier of the thunderbolt; hataḥ—struck.
translation: Vṛtrāsura, bleeding profusely, his two arms cut off at their roots, looked very beautiful, like a flying mountain whose wings have been cut to pieces by Indra.

purport.content: It appears from the statement of this verse that sometimes there are flying mountains and that their wings are cut by the thunderbolt of Indra. Vṛtrāsura's huge body resembled such a mountain.
